unnormalised: Hey Delhiites, how's the air treating you? Not so great, right? Air quality in several parts of the city dipped again this week, hitting 'poor' to 'very poor' levels, according to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). Remember that smog-filled Diwali scene from the movie "Delhi 6"? We don't want to relive that, do we?
normalised: Hey Delhiites, how is the air treating you? Not so great, right? Air quality in several parts of the city dipped again this week, hitting 'poor' to 'very poor' levels, according to the C P C B. Remember that smog-filled Diwali scene from the movie "Delhi six"? We do not want to relive that, do we?

unnormalised: Experts at the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM) are saying a combination of factors like stubble burning in neighbouring states and slow wind speeds are to blame. They are predicting that the situation could worsen before improving later this week.
normalised: Experts at the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (I I T M) are saying a combination of factors like stubble burning in neighboring states and slow wind speeds are to blame. They are predicting that the situation could worsen before improving later this week.

unnormalised: The Delhi government is considering re-implementing measures like odd-even and enhanced parking fees if the air quality continues to decline. Let's all do our bit, folks – carpool, use public transport, and maybe even plant a Tulsi sapling or two. Every little bit helps to clear up our 'hawa' and breathe easier, no? Think of future generations and the need to reduce PM2.5 levels. Every R spent on pollution control now, saves Rs. 100 later.
normalised: The Delhi government is considering re-implementing measures like odd-even and enhanced parking fees if the air quality continues to decline. Let us all do our bit, folks – carpool, use public transport, and maybe even plant a Tulsi sapling or two. Every little bit helps to clear up our 'hawa' and breathe easier, no? Think of future generations and the need to reduce P M two point five levels. Every rupee spent on pollution control now, saves rupees one hundred later.
